WARNING, LONG REVIEW AHEAD. SCROLL DOWN FOR TL;DRTales Runner isn't what it used to be.Do not let the low game time fool you about this review. I only did this so I could write this. I have played Tales Runner since 2008-09 when it was hosted by GPotato, and have been a major fan of the game ever since. The cartoony graphics, quirky maps, and interesting characters are what kept me playing the game for so long. I was playing the game before alchemy was even released, and the most you could get on your stats were about +1 or +2 on specific stats with some items. All I did was play as Charlie (Now named Billy), and I had tons of fun playing with almost anybody no matter what level. Once alchemy was released, that was a completely different story, and everybody had to get their hands on them because it was an interesting concept that made Tales Runner an MMO. At first, it was just something fun to get bonus stats so that you can become stronger as long as you kept your alchemy repaired. Skip ahead two or three years.Gpotato then turned Tales Runner into a pay2win game. With all new pets, the grand Piero alchemy set that all pros including myself needed to get, and trees to put in your farm to get tons of EXP for so that you can level up, Tales Runner started making its downward slope into destroying itself. Finally, Gpotato released the biggest content patch that many users had been waiting so long for... Chaos War. All new Angel and Devil sets were released, multiple Legendary Fire equips (That only came in different colors but came in the near same stats, but required TONS of farming for in game money to claim in their gambling system.) Chaos War brought along new content like turf wars, and chaos maps (Basically maps where you join together with different people to defeat a specific boss.) Everybody only did Guardian Training (Hard) because it was a simple, easy boss that anybody with good amount of skills could do in under 2 minutes to get MASSIVE amounts of EXP and TR. This is where the fun started getting sucked out of the game. That's all people did, as well as The Angry Brother map (Another easy map for those that are skilled that you can finish in only 30 seconds to get tons of EXP.) Now, there are two types of players in Tales Runner: Those that played for fun, and those that played to become the best. I fell under those that only played for fun after I realized that they were taking a game like this so seriously. I had all alchemy upgraded to their final level, most of them Rank S for the best stats that could come on them, every single character, and the skills to back up those items.I even joined in most events that the GMs hosted to get the players to participate in to win for prizes. I won a Tales Runner t-shirt from the Battle Channel that I still keep in my closet as a keepsake, and almost won an Xbox 360. The GMs, specifically Yuui were really some great, friendly people that knew how to do their job correctly. And that was pretty amazing for a game brought over from Korea to the US. Shortly after the release of Kuro, Tales Runner became rather...empty. Before, I used to be able to find a Lizard Crisis (Hard) or Angry Lizard (Hard) room to play in with a full 30 people. Now it was just Brazillians (Not trying to be rude here) that spent tons of money on the game to get the best alchemy, pets, etc, while doing The Angry Brother to get high up in the level rankings, and the usual other high level players spamming Guardian Training (Hard) for more EXP. Gpotato then decided that they needed to shut down the server. Perhaps it was because they already peaked a few years before, or they just weren't having enough people play on their server. I was not too sure. I was devestated that they had shut down a game that was so close to my heart, that I had so many friends on. Luckily, Gpotato left the forums up for a few months after the shut down, and I got a bunch of my old friend's contact information to keep in touch with them, which I still talk to today. I've played on the Korean and Thailand Tales Runner server, though mostly the Korean one, and I can see the clear difference of what makes them differ from Gpotato's and OGplanet's version. They have players that actually play for FUN. This game was originally created to be played for fun with others, even if there was a sense of competition thrown in. I've had tons of laughs for the many years that I've played with on Gpotato's Tales Runner, and the memories will never die out. To keep a hold of those memories, I've played on some of the private servers that Tales Runner veterans have made, like Atomix Tales Runner and Aeon Tales Runner; both of which are shut down now due to money/server hosting issues. When word got to me about the opening of a new, official US Tales Runner server, I jumped onto it as soon as possible, only to realize I was playing a piece of crap disguised as a brick of gold. The game will never be like how it used to be, and it is not even worth to me to start over from the very beginning to try and work my way up the rankings and get all my old alchemy and pets.__________________________________________What OGplanet is TRYING to do with Tales Runner nowEver since with the release on Steam, it seems like OGplanet is trying to reach out to new players in an attempt to bring Tales Runner back into full swing to the way it used to be. But now, since the Korean server is far, far, FAR ahead of the US server now, and the previous US server had so many updates into it, OGplanet is able to implement new content into the game really, really quickly, and have advanced much farther than what Gpotato Tales Runner used to be. Now, some people may think that OG Tales Runner isn't pay2win. Let me shine the light on a few things that clearly make it that way. 1. Buying Astros to buy TR so that you can buy characters and upgrade alchemy faster than having farmed the TR.2. Buying 'candy' to speed up your marriage days so that you can get to the last ranking ring much faster than having done it normally. (Before you had to be with a couple for a whole 365 days in order to get the ring.)3. There is still the aspect of using Astros to easily get the top gear in the game, excluding Legendary Fire gear. (Now unless you're a retard, all you will get is the Black Piero Set and not the Elite Piero Set, unless you want to look really fancy.) This costs roughly 2064 Astros, or $100.You can easily spend money in this game to get what you want, even if it comes down to a matter of skill, which some people forget. I've played with a default "Billy" for quite some time now, and I am still able to easily beat people that have fully geared main meta characters like "Troy", "Lily" and Kai. That says something to me, and shows that people are just buying their way to a sad attempt at victory, rather than playing the game and getting the experience needed to actually get better and enjoy the game. Rather than farming for alchemy cards and TR, people would rather buy their shortcuts, which personally is not my problem, because people are allowed to spend their money the way they want to. I have no say in how others spend their money. So OGplanet is basically reaching out to new players to get more p2w players than they already have in hopes to make even more money to pay for their terrible, laggy servers.All I can say now is, R.I.P. Tales Runner. Thanks for all the good times, and friends that I've made on the old Gpotato server. tl;dr - The game is pay2win, and is not like how it used to be. Only play it if you're incredibly bored and have nothing else to do.And these new names for the characters are absolutely terrible. OGplanet, just give it up.

												This is coming from someone who doesn't think winning is everything. I played this game since it first appeared on Gpotato all those years ago and then WinnerHub. Firstly this is not PAY-2-WIN as many think.Firstly, yes alot of items are real-money, however you have daily missions and some little events in the park to get timed cash items, some are not timed however which is good. It is not heavily stacked against you. A lot of the cash items you don't even need to enjoy the game or play it. Only 1 or two for the event maps but that is for the hardest stage, you can play the normal and easy stage for free and if you befriend someone who can get into the paid-rooms, they can invite you! So don't feel like you will never get into them.However, because many players are in the Event/Co-op maps (read below) you won't really need stats because they cannot push you around or hurt you with their fury! so really stats are only needed if you play the single-races which can be hard to get people for.Pros:- Daily racing missions for items with stats/bonuses- TR is easy to get- Characters are cheaper then they once were- Leveling is easy- Can have items on as a costume (no effects) with effecting clothing underneithCon:- Some items are confusing on what they do- Hardly any item rooms- People hang in Event Map/Pro channel- Card hunting is more of a pain here- Server seems kinda emptishNow, people will mostly be in the event channel this is bad and good. Bad because it can get boring but also the fact you be having trouble finding people for maps you want to play. A lot of maps are ignored sadly.It is good however because people will not see your level and kick you, unlike other modes where they will judge you unless you are Sandel+ (The Main Quests should get you up to sock+)However this is bad for true new players. On the event map you need to live to get rewards at the end but you could always hang back and get the exp/money off the floor. If you don't know how to dash-jump however you will have problems.The server has died from when I first saw it but I don't mind. Plenty of people to find and play with and a lot of high levels are not judgemental as others think they are or want you to believe. At sock level, a high ranker was happy to race with me and even give me a chance to show him I could do the co-op maps  just as good as they could. Because the server is not massive as it used to be I am seeing these people more often and having a great time with them. I not came across anyone yet who asked the host to kick me because of my low level compared to theirs, infact many stuck up for me. I say give this game a go but I would research how to Dash-Jump first because you will need it to keep up with the players as many are returning players from the other versions that were shut down. Otherwise the community is lovely as far as I have seen  and actually the nicest one I have found in years in the Tales Runner gaming community.

												As a casual Tales Runner player for the last seven years I wanted to give an actual review for this game of which most of the other steam reviews are not.Tl;dr: Overall Tales Runner is a very fun game that offers a large amount content for players to enjoy.  It is a game that rewards skill much more than having the best gear. It can be played either hardcore or casually and its microtransactions only offer convenience.The ReviewTales Runner is primarily a social game. It is a very difficult game to enjoy if you are looking for a single player experience as the game revolves around racing with and against other players. It is also a game that can be played and enjoyed casually due to the lack of a need to maintain gear in order to win races.The game was originally released in 2005 on its native Korean server and as such has relatively dated graphics when compared to more modern games. The graphics with its anime inspired design, however, has allowed the game to age much better than many of its contemporaries. The game, unfortunately, only supports a 800/600 resolution so if it is not played in windows mode the graphics may be stretched and distorted. I personally would recommend playing in windowed mode as the difference in overal graphic quality is significant.The game features numerous maps to race in and is adding more with every patch. As such there is enough content that it is rather difficult to become bored with the game. Certain maps, however, are preferred by the community much more than others as such certain maps are nearly completely unplayed such as the animal racing and 20 player co-op maps. There are farms which function like your standard mmo housing system, and a park that features various minigames and offers a place to socialize with other players. There are also various missions for those who are looking to challenge themselves or prove their skills.Despite what many of the other reviews may say the game is not pay-to-win. All characters and most items are available for purchase using ingame currency that is earned by playing the game. Those items that are only available as microtransactions only offer convienence that may lessen the grind for the ingame currency and experience. There is no gear that is only available for purchase though microtransactions that provides a large enough advantage over the free options for the game to be considered pay-to-win. Despite that I must say that the early grind for in-game currency and alchemy cards is immense but if you are patient and invest in gear that boost your earnings per race the grind diminishes greatly. It should be noted, however, that if a player wants to maintain a large amount of gear without spending money on microtransactions the grind will will be significant and potentially overbearing. Though if a player is willing to spend money to maintain their gear only about $5 a month is necessary which is less than many subscription based MMOs. Finally, having good gear is completely unnecessary to enjoy the game or to be able to win races. A player's skill is a more important contributor to winning races than having the best gear. The game has daily events that offer players a chance to obtain those items that are only available for real-world currency for free. These daily events function much like a lottery except that there are daily play-time requisites that helps to reduce the number of entries and improves your chance of winning those.Currently the game is having problems with server stability due to recent DDOS attacks. While overall disconnections are infrequent, there are periods of frequent disconnections that can become an inconvenience. Based upon former server performance I expect this issue to be fully addressed soon. Somewhat related to this, the customer service for this game is rather slow and I hope this will be improved in the future.The community is average. There are those who are completely unenjoyable to be around and those who are eager to accept and help a new player. Depending on the game mode (mostly cooperative maps) it is likely to be frequently kicked from a room if you are low leveled. This is by far probably the worst aspect of the community for the new player experience. Other issues with the community involve those who are fequently looking to cause player-player drama but they can be easily avoided.Overall Tales Runner is a very fun game that offers a large amount content for players to enjoy.  It is a game that rewards skill much more than having the best gear. It can be played either hardcore or casually and its microtransactions only offer convenience.

It's a good mmo to play for a month or two and then go on hiatus from (Good players always come back eventually). Talesrunner is a unique, DIFFICULT, fun, but old  foot racing game enjoyed on servers around the world. NOTE: There was an old US server on gpotato that died many years ago, some players have played the game since then on other servers. Also it can be a very amusing social experience where many players share accounts, because they've logged 1000s-10,000s of hours on the game and trust each other completely. Not many games other than WOW and Runescape can accomplish feats like that.Warning: This game is a racing game at it's core with a HIGH difficulty curve. You WILL be terrible compared to good players for MONTHS, even if you have BETTER equips than them, if you do not learn the tricks to going faster, like dash jumping, and don't route out the maps/look at videos of routes. 2nd Warning: The point of this game is to try and get good times on maps and win races. That means that the equips in the game are not important to skilled players unless they're competing with other highly skilled players. I say this because some new players believe this is Pay to Win just because it takes a LONG time to get a lot of good equipment when lvl 1 players can buy many of the good equips with money (not ALL). Yes, it takes a long time to buy equipment and there are some things that can only be bought with real money, like pet resources. HOWEVER, it takes long because it wants you to master that 90% skill part before getting the 10% equips part and because there would not be much else to do. ALSO, the in game real money currency, called Astros, is frequently and easily obtained by trading for the normal in game money you can earn and is NOT against the rules to do so.TL;DR: Try it for a couple days, if you didn't quit already then look up some tutorial videos on youtube or something and set yourself in for the long haul for a game you will never quit forever. (Recommend looking up Dash Jump Tutorial videos and buying 2 new characters, Troy and Kai preferably, before spending in game money on anything else).

												This is an extremely odd mashup of a Elsword and Mario Kart. It is actually *really* fun, but it has been around for a very long time before this Steam release so it has a population of very experienced skilled players. It also has a mechanic where once the first person finishes a race a short timer counts down and when it expires, the race immediately finishes. Because of this, in every one of the 10 or so multiplayer races I've done- I've only actually gotten to the finish line once. Every other time (even if I was in 2nd or 3rd place), the top 1 or 2 racers are so much better than everyone else that nobody else gets to finish the race. To me, this is kind of a deal breaker as far as playing this game a lot. I'm sure I'll pull it out for a race or two once in a while because it really is fun, but it's frustrating to essentially never get to finish a game.
